DOC.HEAD: Offers to Buy Lenin Monument Rejected
With AM-Poland
DOC.TEXT: Officials have rejected an offer by an Italian Communist to buy a statue of Vladimir I. Lenin that was removed from a public square after violent anti-Soviet demonstrations, it was reported Thursday. Robert Napoleone, a member of the Italian Communist Party who owns a Rome publishing house, offered to give the 30-foot monument ``a place worthy of a great revolutionary.'' But the local government council in Nowa Huta, the idustrial suburb built as a model socialist city in 1950s, decided the statue ``cannot be the object of such a transaction,'' according to the state news agency PAP. The council also rejected a proposal by a Warsaw resident ``who was stressing in the offer his financial and political independence,'' PAP said. Demonstrators shouting ``Soviets go home!'' had tried to destroy the statue and clashed with police during protests in November and early December. The statue was quietly removed the night of Dec. 10.
